example[0]: A lot of unkind things were said.
example[1]: Her husband is very unkind to her.
definition[1]: treating people in a way that makes them unhappy or upset. Unkind  sounds rather formal. In everyday English, people usually say mean or nasty
example[2]: Children can be very unkind to each other.
example[4]: Don’t be mean to your sister!
example[5]: It was a mean thing to do.
definition[2]: deliberately unkind, and seeming to enjoy making people unhappy
example[6]: He said some really nasty things before he left.
definition[3]: unkind – used about remarks and actions
example[8]: Joe couldn’t forget the hurtful things she had said.
example[9]: Couples sometimes do hurtful things to each other.
definition[4]: deliberately unkind to someone because you are jealous of them or angry with them
example[10]: The other women were spiteful to her, and gave her the hardest work to do.
example[11]: She watched them with spiteful glee  (=pleasure).
definition[5]: deliberately behaving in a way that is likely to upset, hurt, or cause problems for someone
example[12]: Someone had been spreading malicious rumours about him.
example[13]: There was a malicious smile on her face.
definition[6]: not seeming to care about someone’s problems, and not trying to help them or make them feel better
example[16]: Her parents were very unsympathetic, and told her that she deserved to fail her exam.
definition[7]: very unsympathetic and not caring at all about other people’s feelings
example[18]: Was he hard-hearted enough to leave his son in jail overnight?
example[20]: Why is Jack always so horrible to me?
definition[8]: very unkind and deliberately making people feel unhappy or making them suffer physically
example[21]: Her father was very cruel to her.
definition[9]: extremely unkind and behaving in a very immoral way
definition[10]: extremely unkind and enjoying making other people suffer
example[25]: Their father was a sadistic bully who beat them regularly.
example[26]: He took a certain sadistic pleasure in his job.
definition[11]: not thinking about the effects of your actions on other people
example[27]: It was inconsiderate of him not to say that he would be late.
example[28]: a thoughtless disregard for other people’s feelings
definition[12]: someone who is tactless carelessly says or does things that are likely to upset someone, without realizing what they are doing
example[29]: How could you be so tactless?
definition[13]: behaving in a way that is likely to upset someone, or not seeming to care about someone’s feelings. Insensitive is rather a formal word
example[31]: The article is insensitive to the family and friends of the victim.
example[32]: He later admitted that some of his remarks were ‘insensitive’.
explanation[0]: In everyday English, people usually say mean, nasty, or horrible rather than unkind:
example[33]: The other kids were really mean  to me.
